intro: Ranunculus flabellatus subsp. chaerophyllos, commonly known as the Alpine buttercup, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of Europe and western Asia. It is characterized by its delicate, yellow flowers with five petals and a distinctive, palmate leaf structure. The plant typically grows in alpine meadows and rocky slopes, where it thrives in cool, moist conditions. It is a member of the Ranunculaceae family, known for its showy blooms and often toxic sap. Due to its habitat specificity, it is considered a rare and endangered species in many parts of its range.
